links.evidence: IFN-α is a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, which could inhibit the synthesis of viral RNA and inhibit viral replication and spread.
IFN-α is a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, which could inhibit the synthesis of viral RNA and inhibit viral replication and spread.

In the experts’ consensus statements, it could be also used for treatment of COVID-19 in children [9], IFN-α is the only antiviral drug which is clearly recommended to be used in children with COVID-19.
Adverse reactions of IFN-α mainly include low-grade fever and flu-like symptoms (both in children with intramuscularly injection) [11].
Adverse reactions of IFN-α mainly include low-grade fever and flu-like symptoms (both in children with intramuscularly injection) [11].
IFN-α, combined with ribavirin, which could reduce viral replication, moderated the host response and improved clinical outcome in MERS-CoV infected rhesus macaques [2].
IFN-α, combined with ribavirin, which could reduce viral replication, moderated the host response and improved clinical outcome in MERS-CoV infected rhesus macaques [2].
Growth and development inhibition is more common when combining IFN-α with ribavirin. Suicidal ideation is more common in children (mainly adolescents) compared with adults (2.4%vs. 1%) [12].
Growth and development inhibition is more common when combining IFN-α with ribavirin. Suicidal ideation is more common in children (mainly adolescents) compared with adults (2.4%vs. 1%) [12].
Ribavirin is a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, which has inhibitory effects on RNA viruses and DNA viruses.
Ribavirin is a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, which has inhibitory effects on RNA viruses and DNA viruses.
Intravenous infusion of ribavirin injections at a dose of 10 mg/kg every time (maximum 500 mg every time), 2–3 times daily was recommended for children with COVID-19 [17].
The most common adverse reactions of ribavirin in children include fever (80%), headache (62%), neutropenia (33%), fatigue (30%), etc. [20].

Based on the clinical experiences in treating SARS [13] and MERS [14], LPVr is proposed to treat COVID-19.
The most common adverse reactions of LPVr include diarrhea (adults 19.5%; children 12%), vomiting (adults 6.8%; children 21%), rash (adults 5%; children 12%), etc. [19].

CD tablets were recommended for oral administration in 18–65 years of infected adults at a dose of 0.5 g every time, twice daily [1], for 7 days.
At higher doses of CD, the main adverse reaction is ocular toxicity, which could affect vision
Other adverse reactions of CD include arrhythmia, drug induced psychosis, leukopenia, etc.

Arbidol (umifenovir) is a broad-spectrum antiviral compound approved in Russia and China for prophylaxis and treatment of influenza.
This compound shows activities against numerous DNA and RNA viruses [27].
This compound shows activities against numerous DNA and RNA viruses [27].
Arbidol was found to be effective to SARS-CoV-2 in vitro [28].
Adverse reactions include nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, elevated serum aminotransferase, etc.
